title: IHG sells luxury Hong Kong hotel for $938m
text:

Fri, Jul 10, 2015, 14:38 BST - UK Markets close in 1 hr 52 mins IHG sells luxury Hong Kong hotel for $938m By Ben Martin | Telegraph – 1 hour 11 minutes ago 54.71 +1.00 
Shares (Frankfurt: DI6.F - news ) in the FTSE 100 company surged amid hopes that cash would be returned to investors 
InterContinental Hotels Group has struck a $938m deal to sell its luxury flagship hotel in Hong Kong, sending its shares surging amid hopes of a bumper cash return to investors. 
The five star hotel, which overlooks Victoria Harbour, has been bought by a consortium of investors led by Gaw Capital Partners, a Hong Kong-based private equity house that focuses on property investments. 
IHG, which also owns the Holiday Inn and Crowne Plaza chains, said it would make a $700m pre-tax profit on the disposal and the price agreed was more than analysts had expected. 
The deal follows IHG’s December sale of the Le Grand in Paris for €330m. Shares in the FTSE 100 company jumped 3.1pc on expectations that IHG would now return the proceeds from both disposals to investors. 
Hong Kong skyline 
The Hong Kong sale does not end IHG’s involvement with the luxury hotel, however. As part of the deal, the company retains a management contract that could be extended to as long as 67 years. 
Fees from the agreement will initially amount to about $8m each year, and will rise after the hotel’s new owner refurbishes the property. 
IHG has sold nearly 200 hotels over the past 12 years and returned more than $10bn in cash, as it moves away from owning sites to managing them. 
Richard Solomons, chief executive, said the latest deal “completes the disposals of our major owned assets”. 
The company will announce its decision on cash returns following the Paris and Hong Kong transactions at its full-year results in February. Analysts at Citigroup (NYSE: C - news ) cautioned that IHG could decide to use the money for acquisitions instead. 
Indeed, speculation of M&A in the sector has been growing and there has been talk that IHG could merge with American giant Starwood Hotels & Resorts .
